message: O_K, so uh  had some interesting mail from uh Dan Ellis. Actually, I think he - he|vs: breath|vs: breath|
redirected it to everybody  also  so uh  the P_D_A mikes uh have a  big  bunch of energy at - at uh five hertz  uh|vs: breath|vs: breath|vs: breath|
where this came up was that uh I was showing off these wave forms that we have on the web and -|
and uh  I just sort of hadn't noticed this, but that - the major, major component in the wave - in the  second  wave form in that pair of wave forms is actually the air conditioner.|vs: breath|
So.  So. I   I have to be more careful about using that as a - as a -|vs: laugh|vs: laugh|vs: breath|
of the effects of room reverberation. It is- isn't a bad illustration of the effects of uh room  noise.|vs: breath|
So. And then we had this other discussion about um|
whether this affects the dynamic  range,  cuz I know, although we start off with thirty two bits, you end up with uh  sixteen  bits and|vs: breath|
you know, are we getting hurt there? But uh Dan is pretty confident that we're  not,  that - that quantization error is not - is  still  not a significant|
So there was a question of whether we should  change  things here, whether we should  change a capacitor on the input box for that or whether we should|vs: breath|
Yeah, he suggested a smaller capacitor, right? For the P_D_As?|
Right. But then I had some other uh thing- discussions with him and the feeling was  once we start monk- monkeying with that, uh, many other problems could ha- happen.|vs: breath|
And additionally we - we already have a lot of data that's been collected with  that,  so.|
A  simple  thing to do is he - he - he has a - I forget if it - this was in that mail or in the following mail, but he has a - a simple filter, a digital filter that he suggested.|
We just run over the data before we deal with it.|
um The  other  thing that  I  don't know the answer to, but when people are using Feacalc here,|
uh whether they're using it with the high-pass filter option or not.|
I don't know if anybody  knows.  But.|
Yeah. So when we're doing all these things using our software there  is  -|vs: breath|
um if it's - if it's based on the RASTA-P_L_P program,|
which does both P_L_P and RASTA-P_L_P|
uh there is an option there which then comes up through to Feacalc which|vs: mouth|
um allows you to do high-pass filtering and in  general  we like to  do  that,  because  of things like this and|
it's - it's pretty - it's not a very severe|
filter.  Doesn't affect speech frequencies, even pretty low speech frequencies, at  all,  but it's|
What's the  cut-off frequency it used?|vs: breath|
Oh.  I don't know I wrote this a while ago|
Something  like that. Yeah. I mean I think there's some effect above twenty but it's - it's - it's - it's mild.|
So, I mean it probably - there's probably some effect up to a hundred hertz or something but it's - it's pretty mild.|
I don't know in the - in the STRUT implementation of the stuff is there a high-pass filter or a pre- pre-emphasis or something in the -|
Uh. I think we use a pre-emphasis. Yeah.|
So. We - we - we want to go and check that in i- for anything that we're going to use the P_D_ A  mike for.|
uh He says that there's a pretty good roll off in the P_Z_M mikes so|
we don't need - need to worry about them one way or the other but if we  do  make use of the cheap mikes,|
uh we want to be sure to do that - that filtering before we|
process it. And then again if it's|
uh depending on the option that the - our - our software is being run with, it's - it's quite possible that's already being taken care of.|

Did somebody notice it  during  your talk?|
uh  Well.  If they made output they were - they were, you know - they were nice.|
I mean the  thing  is it was|vs: breath|

a new - bold new methods to get rid of uh five hertz noise, so.|vs: breath|
uh But. So it was - it was a bad example in  that  way, but it's - it  still  is - it's the  real   thing  that we  did  get out of the  microphone  at distance, so it wasn't|
it w- it w- wasn't wrong it was inappropriate.  So.|vs: laugh|

is O_ K,  but the thing is|

i- i-  Some  things are going to be hurt.|

like uh - like we look at with the recognizer,|

all the recognizers look at frames. So they - they look at -|

you have a spectrum or a cepstrum.  That's  what I meant by a slice. Yeah. And|

the uh - some M_F_C_C  feature  vectors.|

beginning of the table and|vs: laugh|

and also  the um delay issue so that -|vs: mouth|

very impressive. Well, there is no  real  improvement.|vs: breath|
But it's not wer- worse and it's better - better latency, right?|

uh in some cases when you modify slight - slightly modify the initial condition you end up|vs: breath|
completely somewhere air- somewhere else in the - in the space,  the parameters. So.|vs: breath|vs: breath|

I don't think it indicates something, really.|
I don't - I don't think it means that the new system is more robust or -|vs: breath|
Well, the test would be if you then tried it on one of the other test sets, if -|
Right. So this was Italian, right?|
Yeah. Yeah. It's similar for other  test  sets but I mean|vs: breath|
So then if you take your changes and then -|
from this se- seventy-eight um percent recognition rate  system,|vs: breath|
I could change the transition probabilities for the - the first H_M_M and  it will end up to eighty-nine also.|
By using point five instead of point six, point four  as in the - the H_T_K script.|vs: breath|

Yeah. Yeah I looked at um -  looked at the results when Stephane  did  that and it's - it's really wo- really happens.   I mean th- the only difference is you change the self-loop transition probability by a tenth of a percent  and it causes ten percent difference in the word  error  rate.|vs: breath|vs: laugh|vs: breath|vs: breath|
This really happens. Yeah.|vs: breath|vs: laugh|
A  tenth  of a per  cent.|
Well, we tried - we tried point one, yeah.|

I - I'm sorry f- for point - from - You change at point one  and n- not tenth of a percent, one tenth,  alright ?  Um so from point five - so from point six to point  five  and you get ten percent better.|vs: breath|vs: breath|

And it's -  I think it's what you basically hypothesized in the last meeting  about uh it just being very - and I think you mentioned this in your email too - it's just very um -  you know get stuck in some local minimum and this thing throws you out of it I guess.|vs: breath|vs: breath|vs: breath|vs: breath|

Yeah, but  even  if you use point  five,  I'm not  sure  it will|

on the other  training  set, I mean.|

is the fact that the mismatch|

Well. Yes. So. And that - that says that we could have lots more parameters actually.|

uh f- for most of the um -|

um with many more uh mixtures per state.|

in terms of the expected duration of the silence model? when we did this tweaking of the self-loop?|vs: breath|

The  silence  model expected duration was  really  different. And so in the case where  um  it had a better  score,  the silence model expected duration was much  longer.  So it was like -  it was a better match. I  think   you know if we|vs: breath|vs: breath|vs: breath|vs: breath|

then they do a final set of seven and they quit.|vs: breath|
Seven seems like a lot to me and it also makes the experiments go take a really long time  I mean to do one turn-around of the well matched case takes like a day.|vs: breath|vs: breath|
